thread.title: Marine Le Pen EXTENDS lead in first round of French presidential voting, new polls find
thread.title_full: Marine Le Pen EXTENDS lead in first round of French presidential voting, new polls find

title: Marine Le Pen EXTENDS lead in first round of French presidential voting, new polls find
text:
Marine Le Pen EXTENDS lead in first round of French presidential voting, new polls find Marine Le Pen EXTENDS lead in first round of French presidential voting, new polls find MARINE Le Pen will beat her fellow French presidential hopefuls and is extending her lead over nearest rivals, a host of the latest polls have shown. PUBLISHED: 01:17, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 | UPDATED: 01:51, Wed, Feb 22, 2017 GETTY Marine Le Pen, Emmanuel Macron & Francois Fillon are among the frontrunners for the French electio 
The Front National leader has cemented her position as the frontrunner to win the first round of voting in the French presidential election on April 23. 
An Elabe poll has Marine Le Pen surging ahead of her nearest rivals and snatching 28 per cent of the vote, while her nearest rival and former frontrunner Francois Fillon loiters on 21 per cent of the vote. Related articles Emmanuel Macron demands May pays for migrants in FRANCE 
Centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron, who visited Theresa May in Downing Street yesterday where he announced he wanted to take banks and academics from Britain to France when the UK leaves the clutches of the EU, is struggling on 19 per cent of the vote. 
Benoit Hamon, who has been dubbed the French Jeremy Corbyn, is expected to only win just 13 per cent of the vote, according to the same poll. 
An Ifop poll puts Le Pen on 26 per cent of the vote, while Macron and Fillon trail on 19 per cent each. GETTY Marine Le Pen refused to wear a headscarf when visiting the Grand Mufti in Lebanon 
Hamon would snag just 14 per cent of the vote in the same poll. 
Despite the positive predictions in the first round of presidential voting for Le Pen, pollsters believe the eurosceptic 48-year-old will struggle in the second round of voting on May 7. 
The latest Elabe polls found Macron would clinch 59 per cent of the second round of votes while Le Pen would only win 41 per cent. 
Despite a dominant performance from Macron, the Elabe poll found Le Pen had closed the gap gained and extra six per cent of the vote while the former banker dropped the same amount. Candidates for the 2017 French Presidential Election Mon, January 30, 2017
